H0.text: Who is Head of State of New Zealand. Queen Elizabeth

H1.text: Who is Head of State of New Zealand. Prime Minister of New Zealand

H2.text: Who is Head of State of New Zealand. Governor-General of New Zealand

H3.text: Who is Head of State of New Zealand. E2R

A4.text: The governor-general of New Zealand is the representative of the monarch of New Zealand, currently King Charles III.

A5.text: The Constitution Act 1986 explicitly identifies the monarch as New Zealand's head of state.

A6.text: The New Zealand monarchy is the constitutional system of government in which a hereditary monarch is the sovereign and head of state of New Zealand.

A7.text: All executive authority is vested in the King, and his assent is required for parliament to enact laws and for letters patent and orders in council to have legal effect.

A9.text: New Zealand press releases at The Royal Household website

A10.text: King Charles III at the website of the Government of Canada.

A11.text: Charles III at the website of the Royal Collection Trust.

A12.text: The king is represented by the governor-general, whom he appoints on the advice of the prime minister.

A13.text: Charles III is the country's king and is represented by the governor-general, Cindy Kiro.

A14.text: The current monarch, King Charles III, acceded to the throne following the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, on 8 September 2022 in the United Kingdom.

A15.text: The governor-general personally represents the monarch and performs most of his or her domestic duties in their absence, in accordance with Letters Patent 1983.

A16.text: The New Zealand Government is formally styled [His] Majesty's Government in the Seal of New Zealand Act 1977. This is a reference to the monarch, King Charles III, who is the head of state under the Constitution Act 1986.

A17.text: The king rarely personally exercises his executive powers; since the sovereign does not normally reside in New Zealand, he appoints a governor-general to represent him and exercise most of his powers.

A18.text: The Treaty of Waitangi (signed 6 February 1840) established British sovereignty over New Zealand and made the British monarch New Zealand’s head of state.

A19.text: The Crown sits at the pinnacle of the New Zealand Defence Force, and the governor‑general is commander‑in‑chief authorized to raise and maintain the armed forces.
